<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module2_mcq_q4')" data-correct-answer="D">
  <strong style="display: block;">What does a stock's beta (β) measure?</strong>

  <label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q4" value="A"> A. The stock's total risk, including both market and firm-specific factors.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q4" value="B"> B. The sensitivity of the stock's return to fluctuations in the company's own earnings.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q4" value="C"> C. The stock's average historical return compared to the market.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q4" value="D"> D. The sensitivity of the stock's return to the movements of the overall market (systematic risk).</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q4" value="E"> E. The probability that the stock will outperform the market return in a given year.</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module2_mcq_q4" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: D. This is the precise definition of beta: it quantifies how much of a stock's risk is due to broad market factors that cannot be diversified away.
